file_name: gentechholdingsinc_20190808_1-a_ex1a-6 mat ctrct_11776814_ex1a-6 mat ctrct_distributor agreement.pdf

perturbation.original_text: (c) Company warrants and represents that the Products will be free from defects in design, materials and workmanship and conform with any specifications provided.
perturbation.changed_text: (c) Company represents that the Products will conform with any specifications provided.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the warranty clause stating that the products will be free from defects in design, materials, and workmanship, the contract now lacks a legally required warranty of merchantability. Under United States law (specifically, the Uniform Commercial Code), there is an implied warranty that goods sold are merchantable, meaning they are fit for the ordinary purpose for which such goods are used. Omitting the explicit warranty weakens the consumer's ability to claim defects, creating a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Implied Warranty of Merchantability

perturbation.original_text: (a) Indemnification. Each Party (“Indemnifying Party”) shall indemnify, hold harmless and defend the other Party (“Indemnified Party”) and its officers, directors, agents, employees, and affiliates, from and against any and all claims, demands, actions, costs, expenses, liabilities, judgments, causes of action, proceedings, suits, losses and damages of any nature, which are threatened or brought against, or are suffered or incurred by, the Indemnified Party or any such person to the extent caused directly by acts or omissions of the Indemnifying Party relating to this Agreement, including without limitation (i) any negligent or tortious conduct, (ii) any breach of any of the representations, warranties, covenants or conditions of the Indemnifying Party contained in this Agreement, (iii) any violation of applicable laws or regulations, (iv) infringement or violation of any patent, copyright, trade secret, or other proprietary interest of any third party, and (v) any breach of any express or implied warranties relating to the Products, including implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose.
perturbation.changed_text: (a) Indemnification. Each Party (“Indemnifying Party”) shall indemnify, hold harmless and defend the other Party (“Indemnified Party”) and its officers, directors, agents, employees, and affiliates, from and against any and all claims, demands, actions, costs, expenses, liabilities, judgments, causes of action, proceedings, suits, losses and damages of any nature, which are threatened or brought against, or are suffered or incurred by, the Indemnified Party or any such person to the extent caused directly by acts or omissions of the Indemnifying Party relating to this Agreement, including without limitation (i) any negligent or tortious conduct, (ii) any breach of any of the representations, warranties, covenants or conditions of the Indemnifying Party contained in this Agreement, (iii) any violation of applicable laws or regulations, (iv) infringement or violation of any patent, copyright, trade secret, or other proprietary interest of any third party.
perturbation.explanation: By removing section (v) "any breach of any express or implied warranties relating to the Products, including implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose." from the indemnification clause, the contract no longer requires the Indemnifying Party to protect the Indemnified Party from claims arising from breaches of warranties. This introduces a legal contradiction because under the UCC, the distributor may have certain implied warranties which this change fails to protect. This violates the UCC standards and reduces consumer protections.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Indemnification related to breach of warranty

perturbation.original_text: (b) Limitation of Liability.IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE TO THE OTHER FOR ANY SPECIAL, INDIRECT, EXEMPLARY OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES ARISING OUT OF THIS AGREEMENT OR PURCHASE OR USE OF THE PRODUCTS.
perturbation.changed_text: (b) Limitation of Liability. IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE TO THE OTHER FOR ANY EXEMPLARY OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES ARISING OUT OF THIS AGREEMENT OR PURCHASE OR USE OF THE PRODUCTS.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase "SPECIAL, INDIRECT," from the limitation of liability clause, the agreement exposes each party to liability for special or indirect damages. While agreements can limit liability, completely eliminating liability for all damages can be problematic, especially in cases of gross negligence or willful misconduct, potentially conflicting with established common law principles that prevent parties from contracting out of such conduct. Depending on the specific factual situation and jurisdiction, a court may refuse to enforce a limitation of liability clause if it is unconscionable or violates public policy.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law Principles of Unconscionability and Public Policy (Vary by State, but generally applicable in the USA)
